channel.title: BBC News - Latin America & Caribbean
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Mexican drug cartel threatens to kill TV reporter
item.description: In a video featuring heavily armed men the prominent female journalist is accused of unfair coverage.

item.title: Lionel Messi agrees Paris St-Germain deal after Barcelona exit - Guillem Balague
item.description: Lionel Messi agrees a two-year deal to join Paris St-Germain after leaving Barcelona, says BBC Sport columnist Guillem Balague.

item.title: Climate change: At-risk nations fear extinction after IPCC report
item.description: The most vulnerable developing countries plead for action after a stark warning from a UN panel.

item.title: Cuba allows small and medium-sized private businesses
item.description: Up to 100 employees will now be allowed in private companies, in a major shift after mass protests.

item.title: Climate change: Low-income countries 'can't keep up' with impacts
item.description: Officials warn that the severity of natural disasters is outpacing efforts to prevent their damage.

item.title: Men's Olympic football: Brazil defend title with win over Spain
item.description: Brazil defend their Olympic men's football title following a dramatic extra-time victory over Spain.

item.title: Nicaragua opposition party barred from elections
item.description: President Daniel Ortega has been accused of trying to silence those who wish to stand against him.

item.title: Children's home fire: 'The souls of our daughters are still there'
item.description: The mothers of teenage girls who died in a 2017 fire at a children's home in Guatemala want justice.

item.title: Pedro Castillo: The primary school teacher who became Peru's president
item.description: The meteoric rise of leftist Pedro Castillo has shaken Peru's political and business elite.

item.title: Brazil: Why are so many pregnant women dying from Covid?
item.description: One in five women that died from coronavirus in Brazil did not have access to an intensive care unit.

item.title: Excitement over wooden shipwreck found in Antigua's seabed
item.description: Historians believe the wreck found in Antigua to be the 1762 Beaumont, a French merchant ship.

item.title: The 19th-Century Brazilian who fought US segregation
item.description: A black Brazilian immigrant was the first person in US history to challenge segregation in a courtroom

item.title: Trading sex for cosmetic surgery in Mexico's narco capital
item.description: The influence of narcos has caused many women to undergo cosmetic surgery in Mexico's Sinaloa state.

item.title: Lionel Messi: Barcelona star in tears as he receives ovation news conference
item.description: Lionel Messi is distraught as he receives a standing ovation from team-mates, journalists, officials and his family at a news conference confirming his departure from Barcelona.

item.title: 'Quicker, faster, better!' - Thompson-Herah's 'double-double'
item.description: Elaine Thompson-Herah confirms her place among the pantheon of sprint greats as she completes an Olympic 100m-200m double for the second time with a sensational victory in Tokyo.

item.title: Covid vaccines: Tourists head to the US to get vaccinated
item.description: Some tourists are spending thousands of dollars to travel to the US to get a coronavirus vaccine.

item.title: Petrol bombs thrown at Cuban embassy in Paris
item.description: Cuba's foreign ministry has released surveillance footage of the attack at its embassy in France.

item.title: Dust devil almost takes out football players at match in Bolivia
item.description: The whirlwind, often mistaken for a tornado, came as a shock but appeared to cause no damage in Bolivia.

item.title: Floridians rally in support of Cuban protesters
item.description: Across Florida, Cuban-Americans have been rallying to show their support for protests in Cuba.
